key_title: Key to the species of Agrostis

Key to the families of Monocotyledons
Key to the genera of Poaceae

source.author: Walsh, N.G.
source.title: Poaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons
source.citation: From: Walsh, N.G. (1994). Poaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Palea absent or minute (less than one-third the length of the lemma); fine, chiefly montane to alpine grasses
Palea present, at least half as long as lemma
Lemma conspicuously awned from near the middle (awn longer than lemma)
Lemma not awned (rarely, in A. muelleriana and A. australiensis, with a fine awn no longer than the lemma attached shortly below the apex)
Anthers <0.6 mm long; spikelets mostly <2.0 (rarely to 3) mm long
Anthers 0.8 mm long or more; spikelets 2–3.5 mm long
Widest leaf blades 2 mm wide or more; forest grasses, mostly >40 cm high, or rarely, high-altitude plants <40 cm high
Widest leaf blades <2 mm wide; mostly high-altitude sites (but occasionally in lowlands), often in treeless areas; plants mostly <40 cm high
Inflorescence mostly 12 cm long or more; forest grasses at altitudes mostly below 1200 m
Inflorescence <12 cm long; grasses of higher alps
Pedicels in upper inflorescence branches mostly <2 mm long; inflorescence not widely spreading, more than twice as long as wide; branchlets straight
Pedicels mostly >2 mm long; inflorescence widely spreading, less than twice as long as wide; secondary and smaller branchlets often flexuose
Longer panicle branches more than 3 cm long, remaining somewhat inclined to culm at maturity; spikelets 2–2.7 mm long, lemma at least 0.5 mm shorter than spikelet
Panicle branches no more than 3 cm long (except rarely in some forest forms), soon spreading divaricately from culm; spikelets 1.5–2 mm long, lemma subequal to spikelet

Panicle <12 cm long, usually not fully exserted from upper sheath at anthesis, spikelets weakly to moderately purpled; branches almost appressed to main axis; culms to c. 25 cm high; grass typically of moist, high-altitude, usually treeless sites

Panicle mostly >12 cm long, fully exserted from upper sheath at anthesis, spikelets usually strongly purpled to blackish; branches spreading to inclined, but rarely if ever appressed to main axis; culms to 90 cm high; mostly forest grasses to c. 1100 m altitude, but also occasionally in treeless subalpine heathlands and frost hollows
Plants stoloniferous; ligule longer than wide; panicle contracted, branches 3 cm long or less, with spikelets to near their bases
Plants rhizomatous; ligule longer or shorter than wide; panicle remaining more or less open, longer branches more than 3 cm long, devoid of spikelets toward their bases
Clavate apex of pedicel smooth; ligule of lower leaves mostly wider than long (to 1, rarely 2 mm long); glumes smooth along keel or minutely scabrous in upper half
Clavate apex of pedicel scabrous; ligule of lower leaves mostly longer than wide (up to 6 mm long); glumes scabrous along keel from near base to apex
